attributes.title: 1.	Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical inventory count was conducted on March 2, 2025, to validate the accuracy of stock records by comparing the actual inventory levels with the data in the SAP system. Furthermore, the count evaluated the efficiency of internal controls in managing inventory.

·       The physical stock count revealed the following discrepancies:

Ø  Bread stock showed a shortfall  of 26 Loaves,

Ø  Packing material had  a surplus of +1,608 pieces,

Ø  White flour had a deficit of -2.33 kgs,

Ø  Brown flour had had  a surplus of +3.04kgs,

Ø  Wheat bran had had  a surplus of +1.59kgs,

Ø  Utto experienced a variance of -0.19kgs,

Ø  Other material items had minimal variances.

The table below illustrates the findings:

 Implications:

·       The discrepancies between the book stock and physical stock indicate potential control weaknesses in stock management especially for items like bread, polybags and brown flour.

Significant surplus in packing materials suggests potential recording errors. This may be due to certain polybag packages containing extra pieces.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should strengthen inventory control measures to correct the identified variances and enhance stock accuracy.

Additionally, to maintain accurate inventory records, close monitoring and stricter control measures should be implemented to minimize discrepancies.
attributes.effect:
·       The discrepancies between the book stock and physical stock indicate potential control weaknesses in stock management especially for items like bread, polybags and brown flour.

Significant surplus in packing materials suggests potential recording errors. This may be due to certain polybag packages containing extra pieces.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To address discrepancies and improve inventory control, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Enhanced Inventory Tracking: Implement real-time tracking systems and conduct frequent spot checks to ensure stock accuracy.
  2. Stricter Record-Keeping: Enforce standardized documentation for stock movements, ensuring all transactions are properly recorded in the system.
  3. Regular Reconciliation: Conduct monthly reconciliations between physical stock and book records to detect and resolve variances promptly.

  4. Improved Internal Controls: Strengthen stock access controls, ensuring only authorized personnel handle inventory transactions.

  5. Audit Follow-ups: Schedule follow-up audits to monitor improvements and verify that recommended corrective actions have been implemented effectively.

value: ·       We will work towards strengthening the stock controls in place to ensure we reduce the variances noted to minimal levels
The noted variances are allowable however, manager is advised to remain attentive and work towards minimizing them.

·       In the prior Audit, dated 31st January 2025,the following variances were noted:

ü  Bread stock had a shortfall of -35 Pieces,

ü  Polybags had +2,607 pieces,

ü  White flour had -18.41 Kgs,

ü  Brown flour had + 3.86 kgs,

ü  Wheat Bran had +1.12kgs,

ü  Yeast 125g had +2.91kgs,

ü  Crates had nil variance,

Utto +0.36Litres.
Previous

The physical stock take aimed to:

  1. Verify the accuracy of inventory records by comparing book stock with actual physical stock.
  2. Identify and investigate any discrepancies to assess potential weaknesses in inventory control.
  3. Evaluate the efficiency of stock management procedures and adherence to company policies.
  4. Provide recommendations to strengthen stock accuracy and minimize variances in future audits.

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description:
·       A spot check on March 2, 2025, assessed the weight of packed bread before dispatch to ensure compliance with weight standards.

·       The findings revealed inconsistencies across different bread varieties, with cases of underweight, overweight and correctly weighted bread recorded.

Ø  Incidence of Underweight Bread: Several bread varieties had a significant percentage of underweight samples, including: 200g Ml (60%), 600g CT (60%), 800g CT (56%) and 1.5kg bread (34%).

Ø  Overweight Bread: 600g BW (75%) had a notable percentage of overweight samples.

Ø  Dough Weight Variances: 400g and 800g dough weights also exhibited significant discrepancies, with up to 45% of 400g dough samples being underweight, which could affect the final bread weight.

Implications:

·       The presence of underweight bread in the market may lead to non-compliance with weights and measures regulations, exposing the company to potential fines and legal consequences.

·       Delivering underweight products can result in customer dissatisfaction, damaging the brand’s reputation and potentially leading to loss of market share.

·       Overweight bread could increase costs per unit, affecting profitability without necessarily increasing revenue.

Inconsistencies in dough weight suggest potential production inefficiencies.
attributes.recommendation:
·       While weight controls are effective in many cases, variations in adherence to weight standards suggest a need for stricter enforcement to maintain consistency and product quality.

Branch management is encouraged to establish a weight variance threshold beyond which corrective action must be taken immediately.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To address bread weight inconsistencies and improve compliance, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Strengthen Weight Control Procedures: Implement stricter monitoring of weight checks at each production stage to ensure compliance with set standards.

  2. Random Spot Checks: Increase the frequency of spot checks on packed bread before dispatch to verify compliance with weight regulations.

  3. Set Tolerance Thresholds: Define acceptable weight variance thresholds and implement immediate corrective measures when variances exceed the limit.

  4. Audit Follow-ups: Conduct regular follow-up audits to assess the effectiveness of implemented controls and make necessary adjustments.

value:
·       I'll conduct more random spot checks on weight to ensure compliance.

·       We will follow up with supervisors to maintain weight compliance.

·       The 800g CT had issues due to overcooling, as the supervisor did not follow up.

I'll ensure they follow up properly.
We will ensure weight compliance by following up with supervisors.

·       In the prior audit dated 31st January 2025, it was noted that Underweights in packed breads were as follows;    

ü  400g CTW -43%,

ü  600g-70%,

ü  800 CTW-92%,

ü  400g Long-33%,

ü  200 g Minibread-95%,

ü  400g S/N-75%.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

The bread weight audit test was conducted to:

  1. Ensure compliance with regulatory weight standards for all bread varieties.
  2. Identify any deviations in bread weight that could result in customer dissatisfaction or regulatory penalties.
  3. Assess the effectiveness of production controls in maintaining consistent product weight.
  4. Provide recommendations to improve weight accuracy and minimize underweight or overweight products.

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We reviewed the damages for the period from February 1, 2025, to February 28, 2025, to assess whether there were any instances of damages exceeding the established standard limits of 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.

·       Production damages accounted for 0.22% of total production, exceeding the standard limit by 0.02%, with a cost implication of Ksh 6,841.45,

·       Market damages reached 0.51% of total sales, surpassing the allowable limit by 0.01%, resulting in a cost implication of Ksh 3,188.3.

·       The findings were as detailed below:

Implications

·       Exceeding the allowable damage limits leads to avoidable financial losses, directly impacting profit margins.

Higher-than-expected production damages may indicate defective manufacturing processes.
attributes.recommendation:
·       To adhere to the set quality control parameters within the production process to minimize damages.

Branch management should ensure production equipment and ovens are regularly inspected and maintained to prevent unnecessary damages caused by malfunctions.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To minimize production and market-related damages, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Enhance Quality Control Measures: Implement stricter quality control checks during the production process to detect defects early and reduce damages.

  2. Conduct periodic audits to assess the effectiveness of implemented controls and make necessary adjustments.

value: ·       We shall ensure that we maintain quality bread production and that production process is well followed to reduce damages
We will strengthen controls in place to ensure damages does not exceed the allowed threshold.

·       During the prior audit dated 31st January 2025, it was found that;        

ü  Production bread damages were averaging at 0.24% of the production.

Market damages stood at 0.54% of the sales.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

The damages analysis was conducted to:

  1. Evaluate the percentage of production and market damages in relation to set standard limits.
  2. Identify potential causes of excess damages, whether due to production inefficiencies, handling errors, or storage conditions.
  3. Assess financial implications resulting from excess damages and their impact on profitability.
  4. Provide recommendations to minimize damage occurrences and enhance quality control measures.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the mixing charts and summaries was conducted over a 28-day period, from February 1, 2025, to February 28, 2025, to evaluate whether raw material usage aligned with the established BOM and if production standards were met. The goal of this review was to examine both shift-wise and summarized mixing chart documents, with a particular focus on the branch's Utto oil consumption, average yield and instances of remixes, as outlined below.

·       Below are summary of the findings:

ü  Utto consumption stood at 100%.

ü  Average yield was 192.78 loaves per bag.

ü  Average production was 119.57 bags per day representing 72.69% of the set target of 164.5 bags.

ü  There we no cases remixes for the reviewed period.

·       The table below shows a summarised findings of the mixing chart analysis.

 Findings

·       Daily production was aligned with market demand, as the average daily production (119.57 bags) exceeded the average daily sales demand (111.45 bags) as illustrated below;

Implications:

The branch achieved only 72.69% of its daily production target (164.5 bags), indicating underutilization of production capacity.
attributes.recommendation:
·       The branch management is advised to maintain the current approach of aligning production with market demand to prevent wastage and market damages.

The sales team should intensify efforts to acquire new customers, ensuring optimal utilization of the branch's production capacity.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To improve adherence to the Bill of Materials (BOM) and optimize production efficiency, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Strict Adherence to BOM: Ensure that raw material measurements align with the established BOM to maintain consistency in product quality.
  2. Regular Review of Mixing Charts: Conduct frequent reviews and cross-checks of mixing chart entries to detect errors or inconsistencies.

  3. Audit Follow-ups: Conduct regular audits to verify adherence to BOM and implement necessary corrective actions to improve efficiency.

value: The achieved target was primarily due to balance controls being fully implemented in response to low sales

·       Due to low demand for bread we were not running on full scale thus affecting our targets achievement.

We shall adjust accordingly should there be rise in demand for bread

·       In the prior audit, it was noted that;

ü  Average yield was at 192.61 loaves per bag,

ü  Utto consumption was at 100%,

ü  Average production was at 112.15 bags per day representing 68.39% of the set target of 164 bags.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

The mixing chart analysis was conducted to:

  1. Assess whether raw material usage aligns with the established Bill of Materials (BOM) to maintain production efficiency.
  2. Identify any inconsistencies in ingredient measurements that could affect product quality and yield.
  3. Monitor the consumption of key ingredients such as flour, yeast, and Utto oil to prevent wastage and ensure cost efficiency.
  4. Evaluate production target achievement and recommend process improvements to enhance productivity.

attributes.title: Cash Count
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted in the cash office to verify that the cash on hand matched the cash flow balance and to assess the effectiveness of the existing cash control measures.

·       All cash was properly accounted for, as outlined below:

Implications:

The proper accounting of all cash indicates that the existing cash control procedures are effective in minimizing the risk of misappropriation or discrepancies.
attributes.recommendation: Continue enforcing strict cash handling policies and regular reconciliations to uphold accuracy and accountability.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To strengthen cash handling procedures and minimize discrepancies, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Daily Cash Reconciliation: Ensure daily cash counts and reconciliations between system records and physical cash to detect discrepancies promptly.
  2. Strict Cash Handling Policies: Implement strict procedures for cash collection, storage and disbursement to prevent theft or mismanagement.

value: ·       Cash controls are effective, and we will continue to maintain them.
Cash controls are effective, and we will continue to maintain them.
In a previous audit, it was observed that all cash was fully accounted for.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

The cash verification audit was conducted to:

  1. Ensure that cash balances match recorded financial records, confirming the accuracy of cash handling procedures.
  2. Identify any discrepancies between physical cash and system records to detect potential fraud or errors.
  3. Assess the effectiveness of cash control policies in preventing misappropriation or cash shortages.

attributes.title: Minispot Check
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted at the mini shop on March 3, 2025, to assess whether operations were being carried out in line with the established standards.

·       The audit focused on reconciling stock movements with recorded sales and confirming whether Mpesa transactions aligned with the expected sales figures.

·       The Mpesa till records matched the expected sales, indicating proper reconciliation procedures were followed.

·       However, an extra amount was recorded in the Mpesa till, which was explained as payments received from customers from other routes.

·       The table below illustrates the findings.

Implications:

The presence of payments from other routes in the mini shop Mpesa till could create confusion in financial records, making it difficult to track accurate revenue for each sales point.
attributes.recommendation:
·       The current controls in the mini shop are working effectively and should be sustained, with improvements implemented where necessary.

However, there is a need for proper documentation and approvals for any payments received from other routes to avoid potential misreporting or fund misallocation.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To enhance operational efficiency and financial integrity in mini shop transactions, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Strengthen Sales Recording Procedures: Ensure all transactions are accurately recorded in the system and cross-checked against stock movements.
  2. Enhance Mpesa Reconciliation: Implement daily reconciliations of Mpesa transactions with recorded sales to detect and correct any discrepancies.

value: ·       The controls at the minishop are functioning effectively, but improvements are needed to address issues with payments from other routes.
The controls are effective although the employee is encouraged to ensure other routes payment are accounted fully.
In the prior audit, the findings revealed there was an excess amount at the mini-shop amounting to Kshs 2.34.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

The mini shop spot check was conducted to:

  1. Verify the accuracy of recorded sales transactions against stock movements to ensure proper reconciliation.
  2. Assess compliance with cash handling and Mpesa transaction recording procedures.

  3. Recommend measures to improve mini shop operations, strengthen accountability, and enhance revenue tracking.

attributes.title: Debtor Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balance as at 4 March 2025 was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       The audit identified cases of misappropriation of client funds by turnboys who lacked sufficient security, exposing the branch to potential financial loss. The issue however was under sale representative follow up to ensure funds were recovered.

·       We also noted of dormant accounts which was not sufficiently secured thus requiring sales representative continued follow up.

·       The outstanding debt exclusive of prepayments was KES 1,401,286.80 primarily secured through security deposits, extra cents, Supa Points and well-performing clients with credit limits as detailed in Appendix II below:

Implications:

·       If unsecured balances remain unpaid, they could negatively impact liquidity and operational efficiency.

Misappropriation of client funds by turnboys without adequate security exposes the branch to potential fraud and cash flow issues.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Sales representative is encouraged to actively follow up on overdue balances, particularly unsecured debts, to prevent them from becoming bad debts.

·       An engagement with clients who has outstanding balances is necessary to establish firm repayment commitments.

Implementation of stricter controls over cash handling by turnboys, including requiring adequate security measures is necessary moving forward.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To improve debt management and enhance financial control, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Strict Credit Control Policies: Enforce tighter credit policies to minimize the risk of overdue and bad debts.
  2. Regular Debtor Follow-ups: Implement routine follow-ups on outstanding balances to ensure timely collections.
  3.

value: Sales team are following all outs standing debts.
Sales team are following all outs standing debts.

·       In a previous audit, It was observed that there were nine dormant accounts, while others were blocked, holding a total balance of Ksh 651,670.75

·       The sales representative was actively following up on these cases.

·       Additionally, it was noted that customers Christine Ndinda Musyoka (Ksh 10,185), Thaddeus Kyove Mwathi (Ksh 7,089), and Urbanus Mulele Musyoki (Ksh 10,878) had disputed their outstanding balances, claiming that the funds were taken by the turnboys.

These cases were also under follow-up by the sales representative.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       Production efficiency was assessed over a 28 day period, from February 1, 2025, to February 28, 2025 with the goal of determining whether the hired production workers were meeting the set efficiency target of 4.50 bags.

·       The actual production efficiency achieved was 4.23 bags per worker, falling slightly below the target.

·       The branch hired 12 additional workers beyond the required number, leading to an extra cost of Ksh 13,039.2.

·       A summary of the analysis is shown below;

Implications:

·       The hiring of 12 extra workers led to an avoidable cost of Ksh 13,039.2, reducing overall cost efficiency.

The inability to meet the efficiency target may indicate potential inefficiencies in workforce utilization or production processes.
attributes.recommendation:
·       The branch management is advised to adjust staffing levels to match actual production needs, ensuring that only necessary workers are hired.

·       The branch management is also advised to implement workforce scheduling strategies to enhance efficiency without incurring extra labour costs.
attributes.effect:
The hiring of 12 extra workers led to an avoidable cost of Ksh 13,039.2, reducing overall cost efficiency.

The inability to meet the efficiency target may indicate potential inefficiencies in workforce utilization or production processes.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To improve production efficiency and optimize resource utilization, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Workforce Optimization: Align staffing levels with actual production needs to minimize unnecessary labor costs.
  2. Performance Monitoring: Track production efficiency metrics regularly and implement corrective actions when targets are not met.
  3. Equipment Maintenance: Conduct routine maintenance and timely repairs to prevent equipment breakdowns that impact productivity.

value: ·       The production for the period in unit two had shifts cuts due to low sales thus affecting the overall efficiency.
There were notable improvements in production efficiency, though we are continuing to push toward achieving the targets.

·       In the prior audit;

Production efficiency was 4.18 Bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       The efficiency of human resource allocation in the packing area was evaluated by measuring packing efficiency over a 28-day period, from February 1, 2025, to February 28, 2025.

·       The assessment aimed to determine whether the company’s standard of 97 crates per slicer was being met.

·       The actual slicing efficiency recorded was 92 crates per slicer, which fell below the target of 97 crates per slicer.

·       22 additional packers were hired beyond the required number, resulting in an extra cost of Ksh 20,064.

·       The table below illustrates the findings;-

Implications:

·       With an actual slicing efficiency of 92 crates per slicer, the branch failed to meet the target of 97 crates per slicer, indicating potential inefficiencies in the packing process.

The hiring of more workers than required suggests inefficiencies in workforce planning and allocation, leading to avoidable operational costs.
attributes.recommendation:
•   Management should optimize human resource allocation in the packing area by aligning the number of hired packers with actual production needs to reduce excess labour costs.

  • Regular monitoring and evaluation of packing efficiency should be conducted to identify and address inefficiencies promptly.
attributes.effect:
•   With an actual slicing efficiency of 92 crates per slicer, the branch failed to meet the target of 97 crates per slicer, indicating potential inefficiencies in the packing process.

  • The hiring of more workers than required suggests inefficiencies in workforce planning and allocation, leading to avoidable operational costs.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To enhance packing efficiency and reduce operational costs, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Optimize Workforce Allocation: Adjust the number of packers hired to match actual production requirements and avoid excessive labor costs.
  2. Monitor Packing Efficiency: Track the number of crates packed per slicer daily to ensure the set targets are consistently met.

value: We are doing follow up to ensure that packers attain the efficiency required and that there is no jam in the branch which can affect bread weights
The controls in place are working effectively although we are working to ensure that packers attain the efficiency required.
In the prior audit, the finding revealed that the average slicing efficiency was 87.11 crates per slicer.

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We conducted an analysis of the generator’s fuel consumption rate as at 28 February 2025 to determine if the Consumption rate was within the set standards.

·       We noted that the Fuel consumption rate for unit one the period 1 February to 28 February 2025 was 23.61 Litres/Hour as per tracker system as detailed below while unit two consumption rate stood at 21.09 Litres/Hour.

·       The fuel gauge of the Unit Two generator was faulty and refuelling was conducted based on estimations rather than following the instructions provided by the fleet team.

Implications:

The fuel consumption records had minimal variances although calibration is necessary for reconciliation purposes.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should uphold the existing controls and ensure proper calibration is conducted to facilitate accurate reconciliation between the two records.
attributes.remediation_plan:
o optimize fuel consumption and improve generator efficiency, the following remediation plan is recommended:

  1. Routine Maintenance: Schedule regular servicing and maintenance of the generator to ensure it operates at peak efficiency and prevent excessive fuel consumption.
  2. Fuel Usage Monitoring: Implement a fuel tracking system to monitor fuel usage and detect any irregularities or excessive consumption.
  3. Calibration of Fuel Gauges: Ensure that fuel gauges are accurately calibrated to provide precise readings and prevent overestimation or underestimation of fuel usage.

value:
• The generator's consumption was within the set standards.

  • We shall liaise with fleet management team to ensure  unit two gauge is repaired
The generator’s consumption was within the standards although we are doing follow up  to ensure unit two generator is having a functional gauge
